comments.commentBody: Yes, but not often.

Reading this is amazing and brings back so many memories. I was a straight-A student all through school. Once I realized that perfect attendance was not always the ultimate goal, I used to take days off every once in a while, especially in middle school. My mom was quite nice about allowing me to take days when I was feeling vaguely 'sick' or 'stuffy.' I forgot about doing so throughout high school, college, my master's program, and the first two years of my PhD when my goal was to be the 'perfect student.' Now that I am researching and writing my dissertation, I often have to take mental health days to maintain my sanity. It took me (with the help of some friends) a while to convince myself that it was OK that I did this. Now I am the biggest advocate for such days.

Throughout my long grad school journey, I have found that my worst critic is myself. I am not just speaking academically, but also in my social interactions and in my hobbies. I always want everything to go perfectly all the time. I am a pretty laid back person about what other people do, but I expect a lot from myself. I am pretty certain that my mother recognized my tendency towards perfectionism from an early age and she was able to provide the space for me to take a day off. Ever since I left home for college, when I return home, she has a new book (fiction) waiting for me to hide in my room and read. She does not care if I spend time with her, but she wants me to relax when I am home. She has never told me this, but she knows.

Have the skeptics on this board stopped to consider that children might need mental health days for reasons besides overscheduling? Growing up is hard work. I salute the parents and children who can trust each other enough to communicate openly about all kinds of learning, including learning when to take a deep breath in order to ensure future productivity.
Thank you Russ, I can't tell you how depressed I am about this loss. You have been so brave in your votes. I would like to think that would be rewarded in some way, but once again I am disappointed.
Of all the losses that Dems suffered this one disappoints me most. Good luck Senator Feingold.  We always knew you were on our side.
Russ Feingold for President!

WE did NOT vote for the kind of change Obama was pushing.  47% of America did NOT vote for Obama in 2008.  We are a center-right country; call it center if you don't like the idea of the word right.  At any rate, the fact that Obama and the Democrat machine rammed through legislation did not sit well with some of the 47%.

Like #8 posted, I too vote Russ Feingold for President 2012 or 2016 or both-I don't carte.
He does the term statesman proud. Wisconsin should be extra proud to have had a senator of his stature.
I'll miss you, Russ. I'll miss you so damn much.

There is a lot of misinformation both in this article and in the comments. First, the best evidence so far is that the outcome of this election did not reflect changes in preference by Wisconsin voters, but differences in turnout. The turnout in wealthy suburban counties was way up, but down in urban areas. The urban vote still went for Feingold by a substantial margin. Turnout was down by young people who support Democrats disproportionately. 36 percent of Wisconsinites identify themselves as conservatives. The rest are either moderates or liberals. More Wisconsinites still identify themselves as Democrats than as Republicans. The data showing about equal spending by both candidates refer to the candidates' own campaigns, not the secretly financed "independent" groups whose ads in my experience were overwhelmingly anti-Feingold. Right wing and Republican groups flooded the state with advertising because both the senate seat and the governor were up for election. Johnson appeared as a gentle, soft-spoken person who was extremely vague on many issues, is definitely conservative, but cannot be compared to the likes of Angle and O'Donnell. Feingold discouraged advertising by outside groups which favored him whereas Johnson enouraged outside spending. The Wisconsin outcome is directly comparable to other North Central states like Minnesota and Michigan. Feingold had the misfortune to have to run in an election where anti-incumbency was paramount. He most likely would have won at any other time. This election shows nothing about the long-term situation in Wisconsin. It was probably a fluke, and the state will probably revert to its norm in the next election.

More:

http://www.jsonline.com...
If it's true that Republicans win when voter turn out is low, can there ever be a mandate for Republican ideas? Can they ever claim more than the acquiescence of the disinterested?

Wisconsin messed up and will be remembered as a State condemned to it's own ignorance. I only hope Feingold helps leads the Democrats to some sanity in 2012.

It's time to give Independents their own label on the ballot sheet. I never understood what they stood for anyway. They appear to be flicked, reactive and have little ability to believe in anything for more than a few years. I, for one, am sick of year after year they holding political parties hostage.

While Democrats and Republicans at least do some self reflection once in awhile, these so called independents seem to swing anywhere it's popular to go.

Sad, but he did three terms in the Senate and did some good, why make a career out of it like all the rest of them? The Senate should have two term limit and congress three. The mid west has had the worst of unemployment, and after several years, it's time for someone new.

Mr. Feingold will be missed. His voting record showed foresight and guts in what was truely representative of democratic ideals. If only other democratic officials had the same honorable conviction instead of bellying up under political pressure.
I fear that Australian-run Fox "News" is winning the war against America.  Sick how stupid and gullible their viewers are.

So why are taxpayers subsidizing the dorms and associated physical plant of the university? Let these students live at home and take the full curriculum online, savings enormous amounts of money and letting them work at their own pace.

In fact we need a free online university NOW, created as a public good, and we need to shut down the vast majority of brick-and-mortar colleges, which are subsidized to the tune of over $100 billion annually and continue to jack up tuition rates.

Russ Feingold was one of the few American politicians I had respect and admiration for.

I respected him because he always knew where he stood. He is honest and his positions were clear, well thought out, and he makes his arguments compelling and straight forward, and he doesn't avoid the hard questions.

He wasn't defeated by some guy in the plastics business. He was defeated by the serious money that was thrown against him by organizations like the US Chamber of Commerce, Crossroads GPS, and an endless stream of money and attack ads and who knows what other seamy political tactics used in a concerted effort to unseat him.

I think that politicians like Feingold in Wisconsin and Grayson in Florida were particularly targeted because of their effectiveness and the fact that the things that they say resonate with many voters throughout the country.

The defeat of these two men is serious defeat for the "democratic wing of the Democratic Party." Fortunately, a far greater proportion of "Blue Dogs" were also defeated, which may slightly mitigate their losses.

I'm an older student (already have undergrad and grad degrees) taking some online computer science courses at a local university. The best thing about the online format is that you don't have to waste time attending or even watching lectures that add no value. Both my courses have an excellent text book and/or printed course notes and I reference those extensively. I haven't listened to even one of the lectures in either course and am doing great in both. I do admit I've never been much of an auditory learner. But, even with that, I see it as totally pointless to waste time listening to someone who is not a professionally trained speaker and who doesn't add much above what is already in the other course materials. I wish my undergrad and grad courses had all been online!!

Mr McConnell and Mr Boehner, I ask you to be the first to withdraw your
health care benefits and other Government funded benefits. Or better still spend a day wi)th an unemployed family with a sick child. Then go back to fantasy land ( of corporate/ lobbyist friends) and block unemployment benefits and repeal health care. Go ahead.

“This was not about Feingold’s record or the money or the advertising. It was about the anger of independents at the status quo.”

- Ken Goldstein, a political scientist at the University of Wisconsin at Madison

If this is true (and I doubt it), then the millions spent on this campaign and (if this is true) others was the biggest waste of money since the war of choice against Iraq - which is just itching to explode into a good ol' fashion civil war.

Money in campaigns matters, professor. Even the "independents" are not immune to the influence of negative campaign ads.

Wake up, professor! Your students might be able to fall asleep in your class, but you have to stay awake!

What has become more apparent in the last campaign is that politicians dare not tell the American people the truth--they dare/can only wave flags, invoke divine intervention, vaguely cite the Constitution, and repeat field tested slogans and canards. To be fair, the people cannot take much of the truth, do not actively seek it out, and generally rate hope higher than fact. It will be particularly interesting to see how the Republicans justify extending the tax cut for the rich while simultaneously moving toward a balanced budget.

History is replete with cautionary tales of those who, seeking more, kill the goose that lays their golden eggs.  With control of the states and the redistricting process, if the Republicans can finesse a way to derail the US economy even further while using Obama and the Democratic Senate as cover, they can secure the White House in 2012 and possibly control of the entire Congress for decades to come.  The real question will be if in their quest to solidify power permanently, will they be able to do so without inadvertently destroying America's economy beyond any hope of real recovery, leaving them with control of nothing more than a quaint dystopian banana republic as the rest of the world moves on.

They'll Cut Benefits to the Disabled, Elderly and Poor, and Taxes on the Rich..!

And Obama will let them...

And here I was worried that the clowns that thought so little of reality based politics would be gone for a while.  I'm thanking my lucky stars having found out that we have a whole lot of voters who, like the Republicans, don't think much of reality.  Cue the circus music!

Let us see how serious our new Emperors are:  Cut Medicare, VA Benefits, Student Loans and Home Mortgage Deductions along with the proverbial punching bags of Medicaid and other poverty directed programs.  Further, while they're at it also cut subsidies to companies sending jobs overseas.  Have I missed anything?
